awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Increasing Student Engagement with Scalable Project-based Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase I project is dedicated to building a scalable project-based learning education technology platform. The technology in this project is based on a chatbot that sustains ongoing, interdisciplinary conversations with each student. The platform is designed to provide middle school students with curriculum materials that expose them to authentic and engaging real-world problems that, over the course of weeks or months, come together to form a cohesive response to a project prompt. The goal of this project is to build and refine this new form of eLearning platform that has the potential to greatly improve engagement and learning outcomes, especially for low-income and minority students. This goal will be achieved by making the standards-aligned educational content meaningful and relevant to the interests of students and by catering the instructional materials to each individual student's skill level so they can move through the materials at their own pace towards mastery. To measure the impact of this technology on student outcomes, this project will involve state-of-the-art efficacy research in accordance with guidelines in the Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA).


This SBIR Phase I project is concerned with developing a forward-looking education platform built around a chatbot that sustains long term, goals-oriented conversations powered by artificial intelligence (AI) and based on a decision tree architecture. The highly-customized chatbot is designed to make project-based learning scalable by empowering students to choose and customize their own project theme from a set of options, and then providing conversational explanations and practice questions that illustrate how Common Core standards apply to the student?s project. This research undertaking will involve developing and training custom neural networks to interpret student responses and questions. It will also involve developing algorithms that correctly identify each student's level of reading comprehension and, independently, conceptual understanding. With an understanding of the student's level, another algorithm will be developed that selects the appropriate materials and resources at the student?s reading comprehension level. These algorithms will be refined through user testing and a preliminary study of the efficacy of this education intervention will be tested in a correlational study with statistical controls.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At Engaging Education, we’ve developed a new kind of digital learning experience using chatbots. On our platform, students learn and practice new concepts through chat-based conversations with an automated digital guide. With this format, we can offer the many of the features and advantages offered by successful online learning platforms. The chatbot identifies areas that need work with diagnostic questions and teaches by sending messages with text, images and videos that meet the student where they are. The chat format has the additional benefit of allowing much more student input during learning, which enables a significantly more interactive and effective learning experience. 

 

This platform is promising because:

  1. Message-based learning is super engaging. The chatbot delivers key ideas in short, digestible messages and requires student input between every few messages. These inputs might be related to their interests, answers to calculations they’ve performed or just confirmation that they understand the content of the last few messages before moving on. The tone of the chatbot is conversational which makes it fun to work through the lesson. The effect is that students are interacting with the learning materials more and are less likely to get distracted than they would reading plain text, watching videos or working through monotonous online learning exercises.

  2. Message-based learning identifies and corrects conceptual misunderstandings during the learning phase. Because the chatbot is constantly asking for user input while teaching, it can check whether the student understands an idea before moving on. Depending on the situation, the chatbot might ask students to self report their understanding (e.g. “does that make sense?”) or use a diagnostic question to test comprehension. When misunderstandings arise, the chatbot can send appropriately targeted explanations. A further benefit is that content developers can use the data about how many students understood each part of the learning materials to improve the content.

  3. Message-based learning offers a truly personalized experience that is more relevant and memorable. In addition to adapting the difficulty of curriculum materials to meet each student’s needs, the chat format allows us to adapt explanations and practice problems to each student’s interests. To achieve this, the chatbot asks students for inputs, such as their favorite sports, foods, places and then weaves the inputs into the teaching materials at predefined locations. With these tools, each lesson can be completely  adapted to the needs and interests of each student, while still following a template that covers the same key ideas for everyone by the end of the lesson. 

Seeing the potential of message-based learning during our early testing phase, we used the SBIR Phase I grant to build upon the basic concept and build a platform that allowed us to create chatbot content and deliver it to students in an easy-to-use-app. The platform consists of user-facing mobile and web apps, an internal dashboard where the content on the apps can be updated in real time and a set of templates and standards for chatbot content creation.

To pilot the technology, we developed a set of mathematics curriculum support materials for a cohort of students Berkeley, California, and Wake County, North Carolina. The students were all attending schools where the adoption of a new curriculum resulted a significant drop in student performance. We developed relationships with the schools and with the parents of affected students, who had organized themselves online to discuss the issues with the curriculum. We launched the beta version of the app and had a total of 318 students sign up and complete at least on lesson. Equipped with feedback from this pilot, we are prepared to enter the next phase of technical and commercial development.

In the wake of COVID-19, with millions of students around the country learning from home, the need for engaging and effective online tools is more evident than ever. To meet the needs of the moment, we’re currently exploring three major directions for the company. The first is continuing down the path of developing our own curriculum materials, the second is licensing the platform to other companies who will use it to deliver their own curriculum materials and the third is to open the platform to the public for anyone to create and publish chatbot content.
